Reviews.Title: Very Good Telly for the Price
Reviews.Author: JT, too.
Reviews.Content: At the time broadcast signals switched from analog to digital in 2009, I decided not to purchase a digital telly because the cost seemed prohibitive on my budget, especially the cost of a smaller screen set as opposed to a larger screen set. Instead, I opted to use the government issued coupons to purchase two converter boxes for my two analog televisions. One of the converter boxes (RCA brand) died within two years of purchase, and the second converter box began to give signs of trouble recently. I realised I had to decide whether or not to purchase another converter box for $30 to $50 average cost, or purchase a digital telly. The decision was not an easy one as both of my analog televisions still work beautifully, and I generally do not replace electronic equipment so long as it is in good working order.I began to weigh the pros and cons. I realised I could easily purchase several more converter boxes before both of my analog televisions "gave up the ghost," and at $30 to $50 average cost per converter box, I decided it was worth it to find out which digital tellies were available for a reasonable cost. As always, I began by looking at reviews on Amazon. This Samsung F5000 series had a huge number of very enthusiastic reviews. I wanted the 22" model as I live in a quite small home and watch telly in my bedroom. After a reasonable search, I found the 22" model on Walmart.com for $166. For an extra $25 I could add the four year extended warranty, and shipment to my local Walmart would be pretty quick. I decided to try it secure in the knowledge that should I not like it for any reason, Walmart would take it back within ninety days of purchase with my receipt.Following are my lists of the pros and cons of Samsung F5000 22" telly:Cons:(1) The plastic stand has to be attached to the telly's column with three screws. I have slender fingers, but I was still unable to position the screws into the slots in order to screw them into place as the holes are located so deeply down within the telly's column. Luckily, I was able to use a needle nose pliers to get the screws into position, and from there I used a phillips screw driver to screw them into place. It took a few minutes to do this, and it was a little frustrating. I would wish subsequent models would have more easily accessible slots for the screws. A buyer is always anxious to get a piece of equipment "up and running," and this sort of immediate slow down at the start is frustrating.(2) The power cord on the 22" model has a "brick" in it. This is for some sort of electrical current conversion, or so I am told. I really wish it did not have a brick as it is just one more thing to sit out and get in the way, not to mention collect dust. On the plus side, the brick is not too large and heavy as was the brick on my old laptop, but still, I would prefer a power cord without a brick. I understand the 32" model does not come with a brick.(3) The speakers are not very good quality. The sound they transmit is not deep and rich like the sound from my analog televisions. Turned up as loud as possible, I can hear the sound from the bedroom (the telly's location) whilst I am in the kitchen, but if there is outside noise, or if the dog barks, it completely drowns out the speakers. I only listen to the telly from the kitchen if I get up to get a drink, but still, the point is that the speakers leave a lot to be desired. The sound they transmit reminds me of those old 9 volt transistor radios we used to have as kids. Yes, you can hear the broadcast, but it is tinny and easily drowned out by ambient noise. The sound is adequate if you are in the room with the telly.(4) The last con, and it is the most significant one for me, is that this television as well as all of the other new digital televisions do not "push out the picture" to my DVD player/recorder. I spoke to a tech at my local telly repair shop, and he explained to me that the old analog sets "pushed out the broadcasts" to other equipment such as a DVD recorder and/or a VCR recorder. DVD and VHS recorders are unable to record from the new digital tellies UNLESS they have their own digital tuners. If you have a DVD recorder or a VHS recorder that does not have its own digital tuner, you will not be able to record over the air broadcasts from this telly. In order to record over the air broadcasts, you must have a recorder with its own digital tuner. Otherwise, either you will have to subscribe to a service such as cable or satellite, or you will have to have a converter box hooked up between the telly and the DVD or VHS recorder.For me, this was an enormous disappointment. One reason I purchased a digital telly was to obviate the need for a converter box. As I mainly watch only PBS, and as my budget is tight, I had neither the need nor the desire to subscribe to cable or to satellite television. The best solution for me now will be to purchase a DVD recorder with its own digital tuner so that I can record programmes that I do not want to miss or that I want to save for some reason, but I will not purchase a DVD recorder with tuner any time soon.Firstly, there are not many models to choose from, and secondly they cost more than the new telly. Moreover, my experience with a relatively recent purchase of a DVD recorder with its own tuner was not good. After I purchased a JVC DVD/VHS combo recorder with its own digital tuner two years ago, the tuner in it died in less than 18 months with less than average use. I paid $250 plus shipping for the DVD/VHS recorder, but the cost to replace the tuner was a whopping $379. The shop told me the cost reflected the fact that JVC no longer produced the part, so they would have to find another DVD recorder from which they could extract a tuner to put into my DVD recorder. Of course, this solution made no economic sense whatsoever. Moreover, I spent $40 for the shop tech to diagnose the problem, which meant that I had basically thrown away well over $300 on the JVC DVD/VCR recorder.Thus, I am wary of purchasing another DVD recorder with tuner at this time. If I decide to purchase another one in future, I definitely will purchase an extended warranty for it. The repair shop tech advised me not to expect from these new televisions and recorders the long life I used to get out of the old ones. Apparently, they simply are not made to last more than a few years, whereas my old analog sets generally lasted me around 15 years, and my old JVC VHS recorder lasted me at least eleven years even though it was used quite heavily. Sadly, I cannot expect to see that kind of product longevity anymore.Pros:(1) I love the slim profile and small foot print of the 22" model. It takes up only a fraction of the table top space that my clunky old 20" analog television took up.(2) I also love the light weight of the 22". It does not feel much heavier than my MacBook Air, which is quite light weight; hence, it is highly portable. For its size and weight, this set fits beautifully on the table in my bedroom, on the counter top in the kitchen, and on the little rolling tea table in my small living room. So, if I ever need to watch it whilst cooking, for example, or if I need to bring it to the living room so that a guest and I can watch together, it will be a doddle to move it from the bedroom.(3) This set tuned in more digital broadcasts than my old converter box. For some reason, my old converter box could tune in my local PBS station, 13.1, but no matter what I did, it never would tune in PBS 13.2, which for me was significant as I view only PBS 99% of the time. This telly tuned in 13.2 without any problems.(4) This telly is estimated to cost only $13 a year to operate based on a usage of five hours per day. I do not know how much it cost me to operate my old analog tellies, but I am sure it was probably at least double this amount. Thus, the savings in operation cost of this telly over my old analog telly will help it pay for itself.(5) The picture quality is quite good. The last few televisions (with one exception) I owned were all Sony brand. I always liked Sony's quality of skin tones over any other brand. As I have not been able to watch my old Sony in a few years due to its converter box dying, I cannot do a side by side comparison, but I estimate that the sharpness and the colour quality of the Samsung F5000 series competes very well indeed with my old Sony. Personally, I am unable to tell the difference between the HD digital picture on this set and the picture on my old analog set, but perhaps that is just me. Perhaps others will be able to discern a significant difference. To my eyes, however, they look the same.(6) Finally, I was able to hook up my DVD player to this telly with minimal effort. It is nice not to have to struggle to connect components.Overall, at this price point, I highly recommend the Samsung F5000 series over its competitors for its compact size, light weight, and very good picture quality. I looked at other brands at Best Buy, but I did not see another brand I liked as well. This 22" Samsung had the best picture compared to other brands of the same or approximate same size. The set is a keeper for me. I have only had it a week or two thus far, but I look forward to finding out how long it will work before I encounter any problems with it.  The main reason I gave it four stars instead of five is because of my disappointment in its inability to "push broadcasts" to my DVD recorder, but I would have the same disappointment in all other brands of these new digital tellies as well.

Reviews.Title: A Great Computer Display (That's Also A Top TV)
Reviews.Author: Ron M
Reviews.Content: No...It does NOT work well for games (or any fast-motion material) plugged in to its baseband video or component inputs......BUT......provided we connect to its HDMI inputs via a latest generation cable such as this...Mediabridge ULTRA Series HDMI Cable (15 Feet) - High-Speed Supports Ethernet, 3D and Audio Return [Newest Standard]...we've suddenly got ourselves a top-quality, anti-glare, high resolution and colour-accurate display with full "plug and play" operation via a single cable into either or both of its HDMI ports.All of which seem to have been custom-made for "dummies" like me.Oh, ...and it's between a half and a fifth the price of similarly-sized dedicated displays, with a top-quality TV that's been "thrown in for free" !And yes...Samsung's little plastic "plinth" stand is a bit "cheap and nasty", but it DOES work ...and none of that "nastiness" is evident when it's actually mounted and in use.However, here's what I reckon to be the real "killer knockout punch"...Toss that little stand away ...and its 75 x 75 VESA mounting holes allow easy and secure attachment for "floating" this fine featherweight above workstations via a variety of suspension systems, from this...Monoprice 3-Way Adjustable Desk Mount Bracket for LCD LED (Max 33 Lbs, 13~30") - Black...to this...LX Desk Mount LCD ArmNot only that, but the huge variety of VESA wall and stand mounts that are available also make it a "natural" for caravan, kitchen and/or bedroom applications.Alternatively, for "Road Warriors" like me, not only does its rear "joystick" button very quickly become intuitive, (allowing full operation in the absence of its supplied remote control) but it also travels perfectly in one of these...Gator G-MONITOR2-GO22 22 Inches Flat Screen Monitor Lightweight Case...breaking neither the back, nor the bank.Hence my "unequivocally recommended" five star rating.

Reviews.Content: I have to say, I agonized over this purchase, going back and forth between different models, reading reviews, etc., and I finally settled on this model. Reviews.Title: please read if you plan to use it as PC monitor
Reviews.Author: matt.mingkee
Reviews.Content: I purchased two of them to replace a 19" TV and a 19" computer monitor.The one used to replace TV...need to reset the video setting at the first time because the appearance was so dark. Resetting brings it back to "normal".PC connection is done through HDMI (use either HDMI or DVI output), but as soon as it is connected, 1920x1080 looks very bad (I say again, VERY BAD), so I changed to 1600x900 and the images look "normal".Now it's the second unit turn. The second unit has exactly same problem as the first unit when connected to a netbook (Toshiba 1366x768 AMD model). Screen looks horrible at 1920x1080, so it is done like the first unit (set the computer resolution to 1600x900).Sound coming through speakers is fine and loud enough.TV reception is fine, but you may want to do some tweaking to fit your taste.---Pro---Space saving with low profile2 HDMI inputs and 1 shared video or component video inputsupports jpgMany picture options and you can tweak it to fit your taste---Con---Horrible 1080p screen through HDMI (set PC resolution to 1600x900 if you want to use it as monitor)External AC adapter.Bad vertical viewing angle (up/down)Conclusion: The TV has good picture quality as long as it's not in 1080p.

Reviews.Title: UnSmart Quality TV
Reviews.Author: SteveSmid
Reviews.Content: My points were--audio out to speakers, USB input, clear motion for football, LED backlight--and this TV has them all.  There is no internet port or ability to connect to Netflix and etc.  It is a simple quality TV.  Amazon had the best price when I investigated.There is a noticeable upgrade to action scenes from my old TV. Definition remains sharp when many things are moving.The USB opens with a built in media player that plays .mkv and other types.  It plays files from internet fine.  The controls are at the bottom of the remote and are too small.  Player does not remember where you stopped, but there is a time display to keep track.Sound quality is great with my Boston Acoustic speakers.LED allows for bright clear picture and deep dark contrasts.  Saves money--it rates at $6 a year cost in electricity--like an LED bulb.You cannot adjust the picture when running the media player, which is inconvenient.  That is when you need it the most.It is lightweight and thin, but that is the style now.  There is a electronic function to view from low or high angles.Having two HDMI plug-ins is okay, but it would be good to have more.You must have a computer with HDMI to use this unit as a monitor.  Works well as a monitor.If you are upgrading from older technology, give yourself some time to get used to the picture.  Soon, your eye will get used to the better performance.  Activate the dynamic LED function--it works well.

Reviews.Title: Very nice little TV
Reviews.Author: Steve G. "Steve G."
Reviews.Content: Contrary to some of the negative reviews, this little TV represents a very nice buy.  The key to appreciating it is understanding the flexibility available to tailor its performance to meet your needs:  use the Menu button to access the performance tweaking capability to go from the standard settings for everything to meet your own particular situation.  I found that the audio sounded pretty tinny and the picture seemed excessively sharp using the as-built settings.  Going into the Menu mode and tweaking the sound and video performance, I balanced out the frequency response so that the speakers sounded quite nice -- even though the do project down through the bottom of the case against a hard counter -- and reduced the contrast, dropped the brightness, and added a little warmth to the picture.  It turns out that modern TV's demand that users take the time to learn to use them so that they fit the eyes and ears of the individual users and rooms:  it's not like the old days when you bought a TV and you were stuck with however it looked and sounded -- the new ones can be made to leap through whatever hoops you like... and it's not really even particularly hard to do.

Reviews.Title: for my 90 yr old mom
Reviews.Author: jarles alberg
Reviews.Content: I ordered this model for my 90 yr. mom, because it could be a "not smart" TV. After reviewing all the smart TV's I could stomach, I finally realized that the smart TV's are designed by nerds who want to make all the decisions for you. I personally do not like my devices telling me what I like to do. I also discovered the nerds limit your ability to scroll to different channels from the 5 choices the smart screen assures you that you want to watch. That means you are having to battle a bunch of stuff just to find a particular channel or show that is different from their choices. I knew that my mom would freak when she tried to use a TV that came up with a million little boxes to go through just to watch TV. I also like the Roku 3 external box as it is easy, so I bought her the external Roku box, mostly so I could leave the smart features off her TV. She just punches the source button, chooses HDMI, and she uses it with Netflix only. It works flawlessly so I didn't have to load all the smart features on her TV. She just disregards most of the remote, and her TV works like a TV. The only thing I do not like about this set is the unwieldy stand that is designed straight from the Jetson age.

It was an experrience TO DIE FOR!  I am beyond happy.  I have my blu ray player plugged in with HDMI cable connection & my old player plugged in with the three prongs--both at the same time.  I can use one or the other.  I have antenna, but that is not the best choice for this 1080p TV.  If you want incoming TV programming to be 1080p. then you need to upgrade the matching technology.  You don't need cable, but you will need additional equipment.  However 1080p is a dream come true for me when I watched Star Trek on HD!  & the Ten Commandments with costumes & jewelry all in HD!  I can't wait to watch the entire Star Trek NG in blu ray!  I am in heaven with this New TV.Note added January 18, 2014.  TV working very well. Reviews.Title: Excellent TV, smallest 1080p panel you can get
Reviews.Author: soren121
Reviews.Content: I bought this TV for my bedroom, and though I wanted a small model that I could place at my bedside, I also wanted a 1080p panel. 21.5" (which is what this TV really is) is just about the smallest size you can get a 1080p panel in.Assembly of the TV was simple enough, but you'll need a magnetic screwdriver to guide the screws into the stand. Inputs on the back include an HDMI port, a combined set of RCA composite/component jacks, an RF jack, and a headphone jack. There's also a USB port and a second HDMI port on the right side. Optical audio out, and maybe VGA, would have been nice additions, but no dice.Picture quality is excellent with adjustments. Vibrant colors and sharp picture. Surprisingly, Samsung keeps the 120Hz motion enhancer off by default (which pleased me!) Sound quality...well, the TV is less than 2 inches thick. It has some WEAK speakers inside. I'd recommend getting external speakers for this TV set. The remote is small and somewhat confusingly laid-out. It also has a backlight, though it is uneven.The surprise feature of this TV, for me, was the USB Media Play. Its video codec support is PHENOMENAL. You can check the user manual for the full table of supported codecs, but what I was most excited about was H.264 support (up to 1080p, High L4.1, 30Mbps), MKV support, AC3 & DTS support, and internal & external subtitle support. It's not a "Smart TV", so it lacks network streaming, but Samsung deserves major props for putting way more effort into this feature than anyone would expect them to.I'd recommend it, on the condition that you get external speakers. It's a shame that the trend in slim TVs has led to awful speakers.

Reviews.Title: Good and flexible
Reviews.Author: Mysterious Reviewer
Reviews.Content: I got this primarily to serve as a monitor with some video capability. As my home-built computer has HDMI out, hook-up was easy and, after a few contrast and back lighting adjustments, I got a very satisfactory desktop.As far as the other capabilities, I have it hooked via an antenna to the local over the air translator system system. The tuner does a good job and is at least as good as our main TV (a 3 year old Visio).I like the fact that this TV will handle 2 HDMI inputs in addition to a component/composite video input. It can read a USB memory stick as well. Both the HDMI and Component video inputs give a very good picture. I have played with the USB input a little and have verified that it recognizes and plays AVI and MP3 files. I have not tried all types of audio and video files to determine which it recognizes but I have verified that it does not recognize wave files or H264 compressed video files.Sound is what you would expect from the tiny built-in speakers but is much better through the headphone jack.The only negatives I have found to date are the location of the headphone jack (on the backside of the set where it is hard to get to in my application) and the limited ability to recognize many audio and video formats (Come on, it's only software). For my application, though, these are only quibbles and not significant disadvantages.Highly recommended with the caveats listed.Penmouse

I tried to minimize these intrusions, but come on, last night the seventh game of the NBA finals was on.And college football is only about two months away.  This Samsung is perfect. Lowering the brightness, contrast and sharpening produced a much better picture.Quibbles: Yes, the speakers are horrible even after fiddling with the equalizer, but you have to expect that from speakers this size. I hooked up earphones instead that sound great. although here is a low hum audible through the ear or head phones when the volume is low, but not annoying enough to warrant returning it. The HDMI and headphone connectors are poorly made—either too loose or too tight.All in all, this TV is a steal for $177 (price on May 10).

Reviews.Author: Marc O'Polo
Reviews.Content: I have rated this unit four stars only because of limited use so far. I fully expect this to be a 5-star purchase.I needed a small flat-panel TV for a guest bedroom. I have a Samsung LCD in my family room and have been pleased with it. (No problems so far after five years of use.) Consumer Reports and reviews here on Amazon steered me once again to Samsung.This 22-inch model was a snap to unpack and set up. The stand is sturdy; it's held in place with self-tapping screws. I make sure to cinch down each screw as I proceed; I find this avoids problems down the road.The unit is plug-and-play. Connect it to a power outlet and a cable jack. Power it up, and it goes into an interactive guided process for setting the various parameters, including scanning for available channels.After the plug-and-play process was complete, I tweaked a couple of the settings through the menu to satisfy my preferences for screen brightness and sound quality. As with any LCD TV, sound quality leaves a lot to be desired. But I find this unit is adequate for the location in which I've placed it and the somewhat limited use it will be receiving.

Reviews.Title: Unsatisfied customer
Reviews.Author: LyrehC
Reviews.Content: I had never had problems with any of my purchases from Amazon, until now. Right from the box, I received a refurbished TV that would reset itself and would not allow me to get past the main menu. I have to admit that I was a bit upset after anticipating my first LED HDTV. I had read so many good reviews about this specific TV and purchasing from this seller but on the contrary, that has not been my experience.  I admit, I took the risk in purchasing a TV that I thought was going to be repaired and refurbished but this was not the case.  Luckily, I was able to call Samsung Technical Support and they helped me to troubleshoot the problem, advising me to plug the TV into the wall outlet rather than my power strip where it would get more electrical power to run it.  I did this and the problem went away temporarily.3 weeks later, the TV started resetting itself again, and again, I could not get past the main menu.  This time, it was still plugged into the wall as advised but the problem seemed worse as I could not turn off my TV because it wouldn't allow me to until after what seemed like 20 automatic resets.  Again, I called Samsung Technical Support to find out that my warranty for service on this TV had expired in October of 2013.  We were in January 2014!  Thank God they were generous enough to send a technician out for a one time favor with no cost to replace the motherboard on the TV.In the meantime, while waiting for Samsung to get back to me, I contacted Amazon's technical support to see if they could provide me with additional assistance.  They were helpful but could not resolve the issue.  The representative ended up assisting me in e-mailing the seller on January 11 to notify them that they could not resolve the issue and requesting for a replacement or a full refund.  The representative from this company, Brandis, responded to them on January 14, and finally called me on January 17 apologizing for the technical problems on my order and said that she would contact the seller to see if I could receive a replacement or a full refund.It is now, January 27, and I still have yet to hear from the seller about whether I will get a replacement or a full refund on my television.  I do not want to take another risk with this TV knowing that I have had to call Samsung technical support twice and that my warranty has already expired on this product.  I hardly write negative reviews on Amazon because I have always had satisfactory experience or above satisfaction experience.  It's unfortunate that I have to write one about this seller, but I've learned to not by anything refurbished again and not from this seller.

Reviews.Title: HDMI - no thanks especially for PC
Reviews.Author: Michael
Reviews.Content: Bought it to replace my old 24" LCD screen with VGA port connected to my desktop, bought new graphic card with HDMI port in it, and new amazon HDMI cable, i thought that HDMI will be much better than VGA, was wrong, VGA is crystal clear picture, colorful & lifeful compare to this TV... if without comparison maybe it's ok picture. WIth HD movies, Blu Ray, DVD... maybe HDMI is little better. And also I got HDMI cable from my friend and his graphic card to make sure that problem not in them.... same thing... then I compare with my friend HDTV same thing... VGA picture quality is crystal clear, try to compare side by side VGA and HDMI you will notice that VGA it brighter and sharper then HD. HD might be more detailed and more contrast but for me/my eyes VGA is better. And I tried to adjust video control on HDTV not helping at all... backlight and viewing angel is ok, but not good enough. Doesn't have VGA, very few Inputs & Outputs. I won't recommend. Try NEC MultiSync E324, so far I love it.

Reviews.Title: Plug & Play Headache
Reviews.Author: Martha Martha
Reviews.Content: I have to agree with VermontMan. For us, set up for this model was hardly plug & play. We currently own 2 Sony HDTVs that were a snap to set up when we purchased them several yrs. ago -- TRULY plug & play. We recently purchased the Samsung to upgrade from our heavy old RCA tube TV that we watch in our kitchen. However, we couldn't get the thing going at all (message: weak or no signal)! After over an hour of reviewing the confusing instructions and diagrams, and going through the setup process over and over again, I finally gave up and packed everything up for a return trip to the store. Anything that complicated to set up, I don't need the aggravation! I put the old TV back in place, connected the cable, plugged it in, and it played beautifully! We'll keep the old one for now.

This problem is systemic in all their LCD's and LED's.  Consumer's have complained all over the internet.  There are even numerous Youtube postings with the exact same problems as in my DEFECTIVE SAMSUNG model, as well as the same DEFECT in many other DEFECTIVE SAMUNG models.
